entry.title: 7 compact and powerful travel routers
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*
Staying connected while traveling is important whether you need to work, want to stream your favorite shows, or just stay in touch with loved ones. However, public Wi-Fi can be unreliable and insecure, and international roaming fees can add up quickly. A travel router can solve these issues by offering secure, fast, and reliable internet access wherever you go.Â Â
â€œUltimately, the big benefit to travel routers is simplifying your connections,â€ says Sâ€¦

entry.title: How junk food outsmarts our brainsâ€”by hiding in our memories
entry.summary:
Cravings may feel impulsive, but new research suggests theyâ€™re often rooted in memory. Scientists have found that the brain encodes high-calorie foods in a way that can quietly influence what we eatâ€”even when weâ€™re not hungry. New research reveals that memories of fatty and sugary foods are encoded in the hippocampus, helping explain why some cravings feel impossible to resist.
The next time you remember a chocolate bar in a desk drawer, your brain might not just be recalling itâ€”it could be actively pushing you to seek it out.
A recent study published in Nature Metabolism suggests that specific neurons in the hippocampus log the sensory and emotional details of calorie-rich food. In mice, these neurons triggered cravings, leading to overeatingâ€”even when the animals werenâ€™t hunâ€¦

entry.title: Banff is stunningâ€”and crowded. Here are 7 alternatives
entry.summary:
A mountain climberâ€”perched on Bugaboo Spire in Bugaboo National Parkâ€”looks out at the sun with the Purcell Mountain Range in the background. From the aurora-lit skies of Canadaâ€™s newest dark sky park to the tiny railway town near one of Canadaâ€™s tallest waterfalls, these under-the-radar spots offer plenty of room to roam.
Youâ€™ve seen the social media posts: the towering and rugged peaks, the glossy, glacial lakes, and the lumbering bears disappearing into thick forests. This is Banff National Park, one of the most beautifulâ€”and famousâ€”places on Earth.Â
According to Banff and Lake Louise Tourism, nearly four million people visited Banff in 2024 alone, andÂ overtourism is a growing concern for Parks Canada. So, right now, itâ€™s an opportune time for travelersÂ to explore alternativâ€¦

entry.title: American Crying
entry.summary: People cry for different reasons and some tend to cry more than others. What makes people cry the most? Tags: crying

entry.title: 7 of the worldâ€™s quirkiest coastal celebrations
entry.summary:
Songkran, or Thailand's Buddhist New Year, is a celebration to cleanse and rejuvenate for the year ahead. On the streets, traditions take on a playful tone, in the form of an almighty water fight. From epic water fights and night-long cave raves to extravagant fruit-laden parades, these kooky events all make the most of the coast.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Thereâ€™s no better way to tap into the soul of a destination than by diving headfirst into a local festival, when communities come alive in the most joyous ways â€” be it dancing, feasting or honouring a time-old tradition. Throw in a coastline, and the magic multiplies: the tang of salt in the air, the lure of the dayâ€™s catch and a backdrop of shifting seascapes all heighten the atmospâ€¦

entry.title: A practical guide to exploring Europe's mighty Danube River
entry.summary:
Danube is a popular river cruising destination in Europe. Saxon puppetry, galleries and gardens: here's how to make the most of a short break in this German city.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Snaking almost 1,800 miles from its source in Germanyâ€™s Black Forest to the Black Sea in Romania, the Danube is best explored slowly. Cruises, the most popular option, provide up-close encounters with the river, allowing you to see plenty in just a week or two. They donâ€™t have to be obvious, with some cracking off-beat options taking you east and into the wilds of the Lower Danube. For an adventure at your own pace, consider hiking on a network of well-developed, marked trails or cycling the long-distance Danube Cycle Path, which largely shadows the râ€¦

entry.title: The worldâ€™s rarest penguins donâ€™t avoid heatâ€”they embrace it
entry.summary:
GalÃ¡pagos penguins populate Isabela Island, where they are joined by marine iguanas. Both animals occupy fissures in the coastlineâ€™s volcanic rock and forage in the ocean. These birds have evolved to withstand the equatorial sun and shelter in volcanic rocks along a subtropical coastline. After 50 years, biologist Dee Boersma continues to learn new things about the species.
Roughly 600 milesÂ off the coast of mainland Ecuador, conservation biologist Dee Boersma cruised in an inflatable Zodiac through the blue waters surrounding BartolomÃ© Island, a small part of the Pacific Ocean archipelago known as the GalÃ¡pagos Islands. She was joined by several other scientists, all of whom scanned the shoreline for an elusive black-and-white seabird. Standing about a foot and a half tall, GalÃ¡paâ€¦

entry.title: How global warming is disrupting life on Earth
entry.summary:
People view artist Luke Jerram's 'Floating Earth' at an urban lake in Wigan, England. The sculpture brought attention to global warming, the worldwide rise in temperature that's causing major climatic changes.  A warmer planet doesnâ€™t just raise temperatures. From wildfires to floods, here's how the climate is changing.
Since the Industrial Revolutionâ€”an event made possible by the use of fossil fuels in everything from power plants to transportationâ€”Earth has gotten hotter.
2024 was the hottest year on record and the first year Earth's temperature surpassed 1.5Â°C (2.7Â°F).
The past 10 years have been the 10 hottest years on record, and a reconstruction of Earth's average temperature over the past 485 million years showed that when the planet warms, catastrophic weatheâ€¦

entry.title: How Antarcticaâ€™s penguins became natureâ€™s daredevils
entry.summary:
Hundreds of emperor juveniles survived jumping into the sea from a 50-foot ice shelf last year. The impact may have been minimized by their small size, plentiful feathers on their belly, and strong breast muscles. From diving off cliffs to starving for months, emperor penguins are continuing to surprise scientists with their ability to adapt to one of the worldâ€™s most extreme environments.
â€œOh my god,Â this thingâ€™s going to die.â€ That was the thought running through the mind of wildlife filmmaker Bertie Gregory when he saw the first juvenile emperor penguin jump off a 50-foot cliff. The bird plummeted downward, splashing into the frigid Southern Ocean. After a few suspenseful seconds, it bobbed to the surface and then swam off toward the horizon. The National Geographic Explorer couâ€¦

entry.title: What â€˜trash heapâ€™ penguins can teach us about survival
entry.summary:
Chinstrap and gentoo penguins, shown here near Danco Island in Antarctica, regularly plunge to depths of over 100 feet on foraging runs. For more than 60 million years, penguins of all kindsâ€”including the opportunistic Magellanic penguinâ€”have been driven by an evolutionary urge to reach beyond their boundaries. Today, many are surfacing in the most unlikely places.
When Pablo â€œPopiâ€Â Borboroglu first visited a remote stretch of shoreline along the eastern coast of Patagonia, in 2008, the National Geographic Explorer was surprised to find penguins making a home there. The Argentine biologist was responding to a call from a nearby rancher who had seen several of the flightless birds on his property. When he arrived, Borboroglu found trash, broken glass, abandoned cars, and burned-out â€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 166 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from March 24 to March 30, 2025. A total of 3,605 panelists responded out of 4,045 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals.Â Â Â Moira Fagan, Research AssociateÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Jacob Poushter, Associate Director, Global Attitudes ResearchSneha Gubbala, Research Analyst Dorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystJonathan Evans, Senior ResearcherJanell Fetterolf, Senior ResearcherShannon Greenwood, Digital [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. How Americans view NATO and U.S. NATO membership
entry.summary: Most Americans feel positively toward NATO. Democrats remain more likely than Republicans to say the U.S. benefits from membership. The post 3. How Americans view NATO and U.S. NATO membership appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. How Americans view the Russia-Ukraine war
entry.summary: 44% of Americans say the U.S. has a responsibility to aid in Ukraine's defense. But the partisan gap on this issue has grown. The post 2. How Americans view the Russia-Ukraine war appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. How Americans view Russia and Putin
entry.summary: Half of Americans see Russia as an enemy of the U.S., down since last year. Views of Russia and Putin remain largely negative. The post 1. How Americans view Russia and Putin appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Republican Opinion Shifts on Russia-Ukraine War
entry.summary: Republicans are less likely than last year to say Russia is an enemy and to say the U.S. has a responsibility to help Ukraine defend itself. The post Republican Opinion Shifts on Russia-Ukraine War appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Views of trade between China and the U.S.
entry.summary: Americans tend to say U.S.-China trade benefits China more, though theyâ€™re skeptical that increased tariffs on China will be good for themselves or the U.S. The post 3. Views of trade between China and the U.S. appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of Chinaâ€™s role in the world
entry.summary: Most Americans say Chinaâ€™s global influence is growing stronger. Still, they tend to see the U.S. as the worldâ€™s top economic and military power. The post 2. Views of Chinaâ€™s role in the world appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. U.S. views of China and Xi
entry.summary: Americans hold largely negative opinions of China and Xi Jinping, but ratings of both have improved slightly since 2024. The post 1. U.S. views of China and Xi appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Negative Views of China Have Softened Slightly Among Americans
entry.summary: Americans see China unfavorably, but the share with this view has dropped for the first time in five years. The post Negative Views of China Have Softened Slightly Among Americans appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: âœš Breaking Out of Chart Software Defaults
entry.summary: Defaults are good for quick and disposable charts. However, when the audience extends beyond yourself, it's time to customize around purpose. Tags: default, editing, highlight

entry.title: Record hunger in Haiti amid rising needs
entry.summary: Escalating armed violence, displacement, economic turmoil and disruptions to local food production are fueling hunger in Haiti and leaving millions at risk, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: No respite for civilians amid unrelenting war and aid access barriers
entry.summary: As Sudanâ€™s civil war grinds on, millions of civilians remain trapped in a relentless cycle of displacement, hunger and violence, while relief efforts are stifled by insecurity and bureaucratic hurdles.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Libyaâ€™s fragile transition plagued by deepening economic and political divides
entry.summary: Libyaâ€™s prolonged political transition is facing renewed strain, with mounting economic pressures and tensions between rival governments threatening the calm that has held since the 2020 ceasefire.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Universal Declaration of Human Rights among new entries to UNESCO Memory of the World Register
entry.summary: The archives of British naturalist Charles Darwin, whose theory of evolution by natural selection revolutionized understanding of nature and humanityâ€™s place within it, are among 74 new additions to a UN list of documentary heritage of universal value.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Rise in violence against civilians in South Sudan
entry.summary: The number of civilians in South Sudan harmed by conventional parties to the conflict and other armed groups increased by 51 per cent in 2024, the UN Mission in the country (UNMISS) said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Alongside conflict, an information war is still happening, warns UNRWA chief
entry.summary: Amid reported Israeli strikes across the Gaza Strip into Thursday that killed at least 23 people, the head of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA, issued an urgent call to â€œget international media into Gazaâ€ to cover the conflict, in addition to those reporters trapped in the enclave.

entry.title: These are the 10 most popular national parks
entry.summary:
Since the U.S. National Park Service (NPS) started keeping records in 1904, its mountain landscapes, seaside wildernesses, and high desert acres have registered more than 16.4 billion visits. Some of the best-known parks experienced record crowds in 2024. Straddling the border between North Carolina and Tennessee, Great Smoky Mountains National Park passed 12 million recreation visits; almost 3.2 million people took in the massive U-shaped valleys and hulking granite peaks carved by ice flows long ago at Montana's Glacier National Park.
Visitors are drawn to the vastness and variety of â€œAmericaâ€™s best idea.â€ From sea to shining sea (as well as in the wilds of Alaska and Hawaii), the NPSâ€™s 85 million acres encompass 150,000 miles of rivers and streams and over 21,000 miles of trails.Â â€¦

entry.title: How to see the northern lightsâ€”and why theyâ€™re more common now
entry.summary:
The northern lights, or aurora borealis, hang above the fishing village of Reine on Norway's Lofoten archipelago. The best places to see this ethereal display are in "auroral zones" that are close to Earth's polesâ€”but sometimes you can see them from even farther north and south.

The aurora borealis and aurora australis have dazzled us in the night sky for centuries. Hereâ€™s what causes themâ€”and where the best places are to catch a glimpse. No matter how many times you see them, the northern lights, or aurora borealisâ€”and their Southern Hemisphere equivalent, the aurora australisâ€”are an ethereal, breathtaking sight. Dancing silently in Earthâ€™s upper atmosphere, they form iridescent sheets of green and red (or sometimes blue and purple) â€¦

entry.title: Is there really a secret city under the pyramids?
Running pros and eye experts say these are the best running sunglasses
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Hang out at a track or scroll through photos of a running event, and youâ€™ll notice that many runners donâ€™t wear sunglasses. But they should. Eye experts consistently advise wearing sunglasses whenever youâ€™re outside to decrease the risk of eye damage and diseases.Â
Quality running sunglasses should be lightweight, so you feel like youâ€™re not even wearing them. They should fit snugly, so they donâ€™t bounce as you move. They should also have sweat-resâ€¦

entry.title: How dragons lost their wicked menaceâ€”and became our friends
entry.summary:
â€œI desired dragons with a profound desire,â€ fantasy writer J.R.R. Tolkien once said about his childhood imagination, captivated as he wasÂ with the creatures of myth. That desire shaped his work for the rest of his life, and Tolkienâ€™s Smaug, the great fire breathing villain of The Hobbit,Â has loomed large in our cultural imaginations, but he was far from alone in his fascination. Â
Cultures around the world told stories about enormous, powerful, serpent-like creatures for centuries. From Mesopotamia to China and ancient Greece, the dragon has slithered alongside humanity, its lore ever-evolving, though many of the tropes are familiar even today: It crouches in caves on piles of gold, reeking of brimstone, waiting for intrepid heroes, or they take to the air, an ominous shadow that passâ€¦

entry.title: What is Good Fridayâ€”and whatâ€™s the meaning behind its name?
entry.summary:
For billions of Christians, Good Friday remains one of the holiest days in the religious calendar. Commemorating the day Jesus died by crucifixion around A.D. 30., Good Friday is a crucial part of the Christian Holy Week, the series of holidays that culminates in Easter, when, according to Christian faith, Jesus returned to life after dying on the cross.Â
Whatâ€™s the context behind Good Fridayâ€”and how do Christians observe it every year?Â Â
Good Friday represents Jesusâ€™ execution at the hands of the Romans. So why do Christians call the holiday â€œgoodâ€?Â
â€œâ€˜Goodâ€™ in this instance means something like â€˜holyâ€™ or â€˜pious.â€™ It is â€˜goodâ€™ because it is â€˜holy,â€™ not because we are supposed to think that crucifixion is a good thing,â€ explainsÂ Candida Moss, Edward Cadbury Professor of Thâ€¦

entry.title: Mary Magdalene probably wasnâ€™t a prostitute. Was she rich?
entry.summary:
This piece is adapted from the second edition of In The Footsteps of Jesus: A Chronicle of His Life and the Origins of Christianity.
Jesus may have traveled to the town that Matthew refers to as Magadan, which could mean Magdala (in fact, certain Greek manuscripts actually use the word â€œMagdalaâ€). Magdala was a major processing center of the Galilean fishing industry. Among others, it was renowned throughout the region for its fish sauce, a popular condiment in Antiquity.
One of Jesusâ€™ followers actually came from Magdala. Her name was Mary, â€œthe Magdalene,â€ but the Gospels give us very little information about her background. Unlike other women named â€œMaryâ€ in the Gospels, Mary Magdalene appears to be unattached, which was unusual. As scholars K. C. Hanson and Douglas Oakman havâ€¦

entry.title: How one divisive herb became an essential part of Thai cooking
entry.summary:
Blue Elephantâ€™s tom yum goong soup is flavoured with coriander root and garnished with the leaves. This grassy herb is one of the worldâ€™s most divisive, but in Thailand itâ€™s an integral part of the cuisine.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Itâ€™s the middle of dinner service at Bo.lan restaurant in Bangkok and our table for two is packed with all the dishes that make up a traditional Thai meal: salad, a laab of minced grey mullet that smells like nutty, toasted rice kernels; curry, a Southern-style chicken-and-prawn version made creamy with cashew nuts; a protein dish â€” stir-fried beef in a sauce thickened with shrimp paste; and much more besides.
I take a bite of stir-fried jÃ­cama (a turnip-like root vegetable) and dried prawns, garlandedâ€¦

entry.title: Security Council urged to support eastern DR Congo peace initiatives
entry.summary: Despite numerous regional and international diplomatic initiatives, the security situation remains critical in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), the Security Council heard on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza faces deepening crisis as aid stocks dwindle
entry.summary: The United Nations on Wednesday warned that escalating hostilities and access constraints in Gaza are exacerbating an already dire humanitarian crisis, displacing hundreds of thousands and depriving civilians of shelter, food and medicine.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Partnerships, increased climate investment crucial for sustainable transition, says UN deputy chief
entry.summary: Addressing the opening of an international forum in Hanoi on partnerships for green growth, UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed on Wednesday emphasized the need for accelerated action to meet global climate and development goals.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Haiti crisis could impact regional and global stability
entry.summary: The situation in Haiti represents â€œone of the most complex and urgent crises in the world with implications for reginal and global stability,â€Â saidÂ Amy Pope, Director General ofÂ International Organisation for Migration (IOM),Â speaking to journalists in New York on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: South Sudan on the brink as peace deal falters, UN warns
entry.summary: South Sudan stands at a dangerous crossroads as rising political tensions threaten to derail a fragile peace deal, amid growing fears of renewed conflict in the worldâ€™s youngest nation, already buckling under a deepening humanitarian crisis.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Humanitarian situation continues to deteriorate in El Fasher, Sudan
entry.summary: Escalating violence and deteriorating humanitarian conditions in and around El Fasher in Sudan continue to be of grave concern, the United Nations said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global growth on recessionary path amid trade tensions and uncertainty
entry.summary: The world economy is on a recessionary trajectory as global growth is expected to slow to 2.3 per cent this year due to escalating trade tensions and uncertainty, the UN trade and development body, UNCTAD, said in a new report published on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Countries finalize historic pandemic agreement after three years of negotiations
entry.summary: In the early hours of Wednesday morning in Geneva, countries finalized a draft global agreement aimed at improving how the world prepares for and responds to pandemics, marking a historic step that will be submitted to the World Health Assembly in May for adoption.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: From the Hospital to the Lab: How We Reported the Snakebite Scandal
entry.summary: Two reporters from The Bureau of Investigating Journalism's global health team explain how they uncovered the shady world of phony snakebite antivenom.

entry.title: 12 travel-friendly flip-flops (plus two bonus picks)
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Flip-flops are the unsung workhorses of footwear. They come in handy when youâ€™re traveling whether youâ€™re padding across hot sand in Hawaii, slipping into something comfortable after a long hike, or simply walking around your hotel. Thatâ€™s why our bags are never without a pair.Â
With so many options to choose from, we asked experts, including podiatrists, and tried out a ton of flip-flops ourselves to find the best options for travelers.Â
â€œA gâ€¦

entry.title: Colossal squid caught on camera for first time in natural habitat
entry.summary:
The colossal squidâ€”one of natureâ€™s most elusive animals, and handily the worldâ€™s most massive squid speciesâ€”was first identified 100 years ago using remains found in the stomach of a sperm whale. Now, for the very first time, one has been filmed alive in its natural oceanic environment.
On March 9, the U.S.-based Schmidt Ocean Instituteâ€™s research vessel, Falkor (too), was exploring the frigid waters close to the South Sandwich Islands, in the southern Atlantic Ocean, as part of an international quest to discover marine life. That day, they deployed a remotely operated submersible down to a depth of almost 2,000 feet, when the colossal squid suddenly drifted past the submersibleâ€™s cameras.
After making sure to verify the footage with a series of experts both on and off the reâ€¦

entry.title: 10 unforgettable ways to explore Minnesota
entry.summary:
Welcome to the Land of 10,000 Lakesâ€”Minnesota! The North Star State offers locals and visitors alike pristine national and state parks, a culture of welcoming communities, and a rich Scandinavian historyâ€”but thatâ€™s only a small portion of what awaits you on this Midwest adventure. If narrowing down your options sounds daunting, we recommend you start with this list of not-to-be-missed experiences in Minnesota.Â
TheÂ Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness (BWCAW) is a million pristine acres of glacially-carved lakes and boreal forest along 150 miles of the Minnesota-Canada borderâ€”the place to go for a remote backcountry experience. Its western edge segues directly intoÂ Voyageurs National Parkâ€™s similarly stunning 218,00 acres. Celebrating its 50th anniversary this year, the park is neaâ€¦

entry.title: Everything to know about Minnesota, the land of 10,000 lakes
entry.summary:
Travelers planning a trip in the United States, specifically the Midwest, should addÂ Â Minnesota to their vacation plans. The Star of the North state has a quiet charm, and its reputation extends beyond its subzero temps and long winters. Visitors can choose a variety of ways to uncover the magic of Minnesota through its epic landscapes and truly unique experiences.Â
Immerse yourself in the natural beauty of Voyageurs National Park, discover the history found along the stunning North Shore of Lake Superior, try a fried candy bar on a stick at the Minnesota State Fair (the Great Minnesota Get-Together), or try the famed Juicy Lucy or an award-winning meal at Hmong restaurant in the Twin Cities. Thereâ€™s something for every type of traveler in the Land of 10,000 Lakes.
Spring:Â Whenâ€¦

entry.title: The best hotels in Minnesota for every type of traveler
entry.summary:
Ribboned by rivers and dotted by more than 10,000 lakes, Minnesotaâ€™s top getaways never stray far from storied waters. The Mississippi River winds through both St. Paul and Minneapolis where urban stays highlight art and architecture in a former convent and coax guests to a rooftop sauna and spa pool overlooking the reflective skyline.Â Follow the Great River Road to the bluffs of southeastern Minnesota, head â€œUp Northâ€ to the heart of Lake Country, or hug Lake Superiorâ€™s rugged coast for cozy shoreline escapes.
Best for:Â Â FoodiesÂ
Gourmands should check into this seven-room boutique hotelâ€”created by Alex and Margo Robertsâ€”hungry. Heady aromas coax visitors inside with spiced almonds, lemon ricotta cookies, and sourdough bread from CafÃ© Alma; roasted duck and Meyer lemon orzo frâ€¦

entry.title: Step back in time to 1775 at this historic inn
entry.summary:
It all started with a bang. Well, more precisely, it was a shotâ€”the â€œshot heard round the worldâ€ that began the Revolutionary War.
On the night of April 18, 1775â€”into the early hours of the 19thâ€”Paul Revere rode directly past the site where I stand, looking up at the Minuteman Statue illuminated by spotlights at twilight. Local historian and leader of the Footsteps of the Revolution tour Fred Silverstein knows the details so well that you would swear that he was actually there himself. â€œPeople are surprised to learn that Revere was not â€œon the opposite shoreâ€ to wait for a signal according to Longfellow,â€ Silverstein explains. â€œHe wasnâ€™t even the first rider summoned to warn Hancock and Adams in Lexington. Revere did arrive in Lexington first, having taken a shorter route with a fasteâ€¦

entry.title: Can you trust your gut? What science reveals about intuition
entry.summary:
There are many times in life when we have to make decisions without having all of the informationâ€”whether thatâ€™s a split-second decision during a crisis or a major life decision such as accepting a new job. In these situations, we often find ourselves relying on our intuition, in the hope that our unconscious knowledge can help us choose the right path.Â
Intuition is theÂ ability to attain knowledge or make decisions without evident rational thought and inference. For a long time, intuition has been thought of as something almost mysticalâ€”something that might be good or might be bad, but that is nonetheless beyond our ability to define let alone quantify how much it really helps us.Â
(Does trusting your doctor's gut feeling lead to better care?)
Even though intuition has beenâ€¦

entry.title: Will we still see fireflies this summer?
entry.summary:
RaphaÃ«l De Cock was 9 years old the day he caught his first firefly, the glowing insect heâ€™d read about with great interest in his grandfatherâ€™s nature books. While exploring the Belgian countryside, he lifted a stone and found a treasure: the larvae of a common glow-worm, a firefly species widespread in Europe, Africa, and Asia.Â
While running back to his grandparentsâ€™ house with the critter, he tripped and lost it in the grass. The insect was gone. But days later, while taking a walk on a humid summer night, De Cock and his grandmother returned to the spot where he lost the firefly and were greeted by a breathtaking sight: Hundreds of little lights were re-creating a starry sky on earth.Â
Yet if De Cock returns to this childhood spot in the countryside, something is missingâ€¦

entry.title: World News in Brief: Relief supplies for Myanmar, invest in Haiti, child migrant deaths in Italy
entry.summary: A plane carrying some 40 metric tonnes of lifesaving aid arrived in Myanmar from Dubai on Tuesday to support survivors of the devastating earthquake last month.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN Youth Forum brings fresh perspectives on sustainable development
entry.summary: Young people from across the globe are meeting at UN Headquarters this week to share their recommendations to transform the world into a fairer, greener and more sustainable place.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israeli strike on hospital â€˜further cripplesâ€™ Gazaâ€™s fragile health system
entry.summary: An Israeli strike on a hospital in southern Gaza on Tuesday has further jeopardized already limited access to lifesaving medical care in the war-torn enclave.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN forum tackles slavery reparations for Africa, people of African descent
entry.summary: The calls for reparatory justice can no longer be ignored, speakers at the fourth session of the United Nations Permanent Forum on African Descent in New York said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israeli strikes in Lebanon continue to kill civilians, UN rights office warns
entry.summary: Israeli military operations in Lebanon have continued to claim civilian lives and destroy vital infrastructure, the UN human rights office warned on Tuesday, raising alarm over mounting violations since a ceasefire agreement took effect last November.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Flooding displaces thousands amid ongoing unrest in eastern DR Congo
entry.summary: Recent severe flooding caused by torrential rains has displaced nearly 10,000 people in Tanganyika province in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), the UN refugee agency, UNHCR, said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: External flow of weapons into Sudan must end, insists UNâ€™s Guterres
entry.summary: Two years to the day since Sudanâ€™s brutal war erupted between rival generals who rejected the peaceful transition to civilian rule after the overthrow of Omar Al-Bashir, UN chief AntÃ³nio Guterres insisted that the world â€œmust not forgetâ€ the suffering of the countryâ€™s people.

entry.title: America has a 740-mile river adventure finally being revealed
entry.summary:
The rain came downÂ in sheets, roiling the surface of Fourth Lake, an oblong crescent in the heart of New Yorkâ€™s Adirondack Mountains and the largest of eight lakes in the Fulton chain. I laid my paddle on my knees and looked around. Our small flotilla of canoes and kayaks, containing a dozen or so paddlers, was spread out over a half mile, though the downpour obscured many of my companions. We were hustling toward the closest takeout, a mile away on Fifth Lake.
Only a few hours earlier, I had shoved off from the tiny hamlet of Old Forge, in upstate New York, pushing east with a group of Native American paddlers along a portion of an ancient route that runs for 740 miles to Maine. The Northern Forest Canoe Trail (NFCT) is made up of a network of more than 80 lakes, ponds, rivers, and sâ€¦

entry.title: This one muscle could be the key to fixing your back pain
entry.summary:
Lower back pain can stab, throb, or ache without warning. But what if the problem wasnâ€™t actually coming from your back?
Itâ€™s easy to blame posture or a pulled muscle. But an overlooked culprit may be buried deeper: your hip flexorsâ€”specifically, the psoas (pronounced so-EZZ).
This ribbon-like muscle curls from the top of your femur, over the front of the pelvis, and up to your lumbar spine and lower ribs. Itâ€™s part of the iliopsoas complex, says Richard Lau, a clinical assistant professor in the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine at NYU Grossman School of Medicineâ€”the muscle group often cited when athletes suffer â€œhip flexor strains.â€
After age 30, everyone loses 4 to 6 percent of their psoas muscle mass every decade, and it decreases even more rapidly for men after 60. â€¦

entry.title: The ancient empire that civilization forgot
entry.summary:
At its height,Â the ancient city of HattuÅŸa, capital of the Hittite civilization, must have been awe-inspiring. Built into a steep hillside in what is today central TÃ¼rkiye, the city was ringed by tall brick walls. It was home to as many as 7,000 people, vast temple complexes, and an imposing stone rampart visible from miles away. Today the hillside is home to a mystery.
No pillars or high walls mark the ruins of the palace and temples that once stoodâ€”just stone foundations half-covered by dry grass. Some of the cityâ€™s gates still stand, guarded by statues of lions, sphinxes, and an axe-wielding god. But much is gone. The mud-brick walls have crumbled over the centuries; floods and snowmelt have eroded the original hillside, sending buildings full of clay tablets cascading down the sloâ€¦

entry.title: How this German city is capitalizing on its spirit of renewal
entry.summary:
The Frauenkirche is a Lutheran church that dates back to the 18th century. Relics of war still linger in this German city but the Saxon capital is defined by a defiant spirit of renewal, with a thriving cultural scene and cutting-edge nightlife.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œSafe travels. And donâ€™t touch the bomb!â€ Itâ€™s a disorientating message to hear crackling through my phone as my Deutsche Bahn train glides through the outer suburbs of Dresden on a chilly, darkening evening. I feel like Billy Pilgrim, the time-travelling protagonist of Kurt Vonnegutâ€™s war novel Slaughterhouse-Five, barrelling headlong into the 1945 firebombing that remains intertwined with the fate of this German city.
But the caller, art historian Dr Rudolf Fischâ€¦

entry.title: The forgotten secret Nazi bases in the Arctic
entry.summary:
The Arctic archipelago of Svalbard is one of the most remote places on earthâ€”more than 500 miles north of Europe, and about as far from the North Pole, it was entirely uninhabited by humans until the late 19th century, aside for a few early attempts by whalers to overwinter that mostly ended in disaster. The original name for this archipelago was â€œSpitsbergen,â€ translated from Dutch it means simply â€œpointy mountains,â€ and from the distance of a ship at sea, thatâ€™s all one sees here: jagged, snow-capped mountains spaced apart by glaciers that push their way between them towards the sea.Â Â
Only on land do you see thereâ€™s more: flocks of seabirds, including fulmars, skuas, and auks, and in summer the bright splotches of orange and purple from the lichen that grows here. Mines were first â€¦

entry.title: Is this really a dire wolf?
entry.summary:
Colossal Biosciences claims to have resurrected dire wolves by giving modern gray wolves DNA extracted from dire wolf fossils. But whether the wolves truly count as a de-extinction is still up for debate.  Genetics and behavior complicate efforts to bring back extinct species.
For over 200,000 years, dire wolves roamed across North Americaâ€”from southern Alberta, Canada to Florida, and even down into Chile. The ancient animals were megafauna hunters, ultimately disappearing with the last giant ground sloths and mastodons about 13,000 years ago. Yet this week, Time proclaimed their second coming with a white wolf on its cover.
The private company Colossal Biosciences claims to have resurrected dire wolves through genetic editing. The resulting trio, named Romuâ€¦

entry.title: How to plan the perfect trip to Williamsburg, Virginia
entry.summary:
A fife and drum band perform in Virginiaâ€™s reconstructed colonial captial of Williamsburg, where American Revolution history is brought to life in the 21st century. This hub of American colonial history features cobblestone streets, botanical gardens, theme parksâ€”and a 300-acre living history museum. Hereâ€™s our guide to where to stay, what to eat, and what to do.
Established in 1699 as the capital of the Virginia colony, Williamsburg is an internationally recognized hub of American colonial history. Its historic center features hundreds of 18th-century buildings along cobblestone streets, presenting a charming juxtaposition of past and present as one of the countryâ€™s earliest planned cities.
Williamsburg forms an integral part of Virginiaâ€™s Historic Triangle, alongside Jamestoâ€¦

entry.title: Donâ€™t leave Tokyo without these must-do experiences
entry.summary: Forget the notion that Tokyo is nothing but a concrete sprawl, neon and crowdsâ€”that tells only a small part of the cityâ€™s story. From centuries-old festivals and calming gardens to cutting-edge galleries and culture classes, these seven experiences will help you discover the many other sides of Japanâ€™s capital.Â Â Fireworks light up the sky over the Sumida River during the Sumida River Fireworks Festival in Tokyo. Every year, around one million people attend Tokyoâ€™s Sumida River Fireworks Festival, the largest and most popular fireworks festival in Japan. With festivals taking place throughout the year in Tokyo, you have a good chance that your trip will coincide with a celebration of some kind. If you feel like braving the summer heat and humidity, head to Koenji on the finaâ€¦

entry.title: Everything you need to know for the perfect Tokyo trip
entry.summary:
In Tokyoâ€™s Harajuku district, the Meiji-jingu, also known as Meiji Shrine, is dedicated to Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken. From transport tips to the best seasons for a visit, hereâ€™s the lowdown on the best way to explore Japan's capital city.
One of the worldâ€™s most populous cities, Tokyo brings together many of the elements that make Japan so popular with travelers. Visit youthful Shibuya and upscale Ginza to experience the modern side of Tokyo, then seek out moments of tradition at Meiji Jingu shrine, Senso-ji temple and Rikugi-en garden. Hike Mt. Takao for a taste of Japanâ€™s great outdoors. Depending on when you come, you could time your visit for cherry blossom season or any number of traditional festivals. And donâ€™t forget the food. From sublime sushi to comforting raâ€¦

entry.title: Milan has a hidden aperitivo scene. Hereâ€™s where the locals go.
entry.summary:
A good spritz is a moment; a great one is a memory. Aperitivo stems from the Latin aperire, which means "to open." And in Milan, you can open up to new experiences, flavors, and unexpected friendships. This pre-dinner ritual is less about sips and bites than taking your time and witnessing the city at its best.
If you want to find the best spots, ask a bartender. These unsung alchemistsâ€”twisting, muddling, and doling out liquid magicâ€”know where Milanâ€™s best-kept secrets lie. Let them be your divining rod to the cityâ€™s best watering holes; a world where every cocktail is a manifesto. Only four customers at a time can fit into BackDoor 43. The bar serves takeaway cocktails, like the Boulevardier. On the lively banks of the Naviglio Grande canal, BackDoor 43 stakes its claâ€¦

entry.title: 8 family-friendly things to do in Tokyo
entry.summary:
Girls eat cotton candy on Takeshita Street in Tokyo's Harajuku area. From a life-size helicopter to a micro-pig cafÃ©, your kids wonâ€™t want to miss these cool attractions on your next trip to Tokyo.
You can thank anime, manga, and Mario Kart for Japanâ€™s consistent popularity with kids. If your kids are chasing PokÃ©mon or digging into their favorite flavor of Pocky, a trip to Tokyo, Japanâ€™s largest city, wonâ€™t disappoint. Its distinctive architecture, fast (fun) food, and collectible culture are perfect for kids. And for families hoping to introduce their kids to Japanese history, nature, and culture, Tokyo feels like a one-stop-shop. Lure the kids in with their favorite shows and games, then surprise and delight them with a city with opportunities for intercultural connection aroundâ€¦

entry.title: Most difficult holes at Augusta
entry.summary: The 12th hole at Augusta National Golf Club, where the Masters is held,â€¦ Tags: golf, Reuters

entry.title: How to plan the perfect trip to this hidden corner of Sardinia
entry.summary:
Sheltering cliffs create ideal swimming conditions at Cala Spinosa beach in Capo Testa. Sardiniaâ€™s Costa Smeralda is this regionâ€™s calling card, but travel beyond and youâ€™ll discover low-key beaches, distinctive food and mysterious Neolithic sites.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€˜Sardinia is out of time and historyâ€™, D H Lawrence wrote in his 1921 travel book Sea and Sardinia. â€˜This land resembles no other place.â€™ More than a century later, his words still ring true in Gallura, which spreads north of the city of Olbia in the Italian islandâ€™s mountainous north east. Although the region is best known for the blue water and white sands of its high-end Costa Smeralda or â€˜Emerald Coastâ€™, elsewhere it has a raw beauty. Wild boars roam its foresteâ€¦

entry.title: Hate cilantro or anchovies? Evolutionary science could explain why.
entry.summary:
Black licorice, oysters, and anchovies are the most hated foods in the U.S., according to an analysis of Instacart purchases and online surveys collected by the grocery delivery service. But many consider these foods a delicacyâ€”so why are certain foods so divisive?
Our early human ancestors may have relied on their sense of taste to identify nutritious new foods and avoid toxins. As a result, scientists think we tend to dislike bitter foods because plant poisonsÂ taste bitter, and we tend to like sweet foods because our brains identify sweetness as glucose, a great source of energy.
But today, with our food designed, engineered, and processed to have an array of flavors, these defense mechanisms arenâ€™t as helpful. With ultra processed foods making up over half of U.S. adultsâ€™ enerâ€¦

entry.title: Sudan: 15 million children require humanitarian assistance after two years of war
entry.summary: The number of children in need of humanitarian assistance in Sudan has doubled as the war between rival militaries enters a third year on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Millions displaced, health system in ruins as Sudan war fuels famine
entry.summary: More than 12.4 million people have been forced from their homes across Sudan â€“ including over 3.3 million refugees who have fled to neighbouring countries â€“ as two years of civil war fuel famine, disease outbreaks and the collapse of the health system.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Gaza aid crisis worsens, South Sudan clashes, Ecuador oil spill update
entry.summary: The humanitarian situation in Gaza is now likely the worst it has been in the 18 months since the outbreak of hostilities, the UN relief coordination office, OCHA, reported on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN forum on People of African Descent examines reparations and AI challenge
entry.summary: The fourth session of the UN Permanent Forum on People of African Descent opened on Monday at United Nations Headquarters in New York.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war: â€˜Darkest chaptersâ€™ ahead as Darfur massacre claims over 100 lives
entry.summary: As Sudanâ€™s devastating war enters its third year, UN rights investigators are warning that its â€œdarkest chaptersâ€ may still lie ahead, following the massacre of more than 100 people at displacement camps in Darfur over the weekend.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Thousands of Gaza patients waiting for urgent medical evacuation
entry.summary: The Israeli bombardment of Al-Ahli, a Gaza City hospital, has put even more pressure on the remaining health facilities in the occupied Palestinian territory, where the delivery of aid and movement of humanitarian workers is highly restricted by the Israeli authorities.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN denounces deadly Palm Sunday attack in Ukraine
entry.summary: The United Nations has condemned the Russian attack on the city of Sumy, Ukraine, on Sunday which reportedly killed at least 34 people, including two children, and injured more than 100 others.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israeli attack puts last functioning hospital in Gaza City out of service
entry.summary: The last functioning hospital in Gaza City has been put out of action by an Israeli strike at the weekend, while a child patient with reported head trauma died while being evacuated, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Monday.

entry.title: Explore the French city that's embraced North African cuisine
entry.summary:
From Marseille's Basilica of Notre Dame de la Garde, visitors can catch a view of the sea and the city below. One of Europeâ€™s most multicultural cities, Marseille is home to a large North African population whose traditional dishes such as Brik pastry â€” sometimes given a modern twist â€” have become a key part of the local culinary culture.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
On the plate is what looks like a fist-sized, deep-fried wonton, perched on a dollop of deep red paste and paired with a wedge of lime.
I crack open the golden pastry shell to reveal a just-cooked egg on a bed of spiced potatoes studded with capers and strewn with luscious flakes of confit tuna.
Here at Marseilleâ€™s Les Rigoles restaurant, chef Johann Barichasse drawsâ€¦

entry.title: Taraji P. Henson on Southern food, travel and Moscato wine
entry.summary:
Taraji talks all things food, travel and Seven Daughters Moscato. The actor discusses the dishes and experiences that have shaped her life, including her grandmotherâ€™s barbecue chicken and discovering incredible vegan sushi in Bali.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Anytime I see a watermelon with black seeds, it takes me straight back to my grandparentsâ€™ backyard in the South. Iâ€™d bust it open as a kid. Its juice would run down my elbows and Iâ€™d have to run away from the bees. One [set of] grandparents had a livestock farm with chickens, cows and pigs, and the other had a produce garden. They lived off the fat of the land. This was in North Carolina and Maryland.
My grandmother makes a barbecue chicken thatâ€™s specific to North and South Câ€¦

entry.title: Resilience in the face of thirst: Trucking water in war-ravaged Gaza
entry.summary: In Gaza, where lack of access to water is an existential threat, Ibrahim Alloush stands out as an unsung hero, providing a lifeline to the thirsty people of the Strip.

entry.title: How is the Sudanese civil war destabilising neighbouring countries?
entry.summary: Since April 2023, Sudan, the third-largest country in Africa, has been embroiled in war, as a brutal battle between government forces and a powerful paramilitary group has exacerbated the nationâ€™s existing crises, including political instability and economic hardship.

entry.summary: Xochimilco, nestled in the heart of Mexico City, is home to the â€˜chinamperos,â€™ farmers who have used indigenous techniques to grow food for centuries. Today, their way of life is under threat from environmental degradation, urban expansion and climate change.

entry.title: 7 must-try adventures on mainland Greece
entry.summary:
The submerged lost city of Pavlopetri lies off the Peloponnese coast. Plot an active break, whether you want to climb up a mountain rife with myths or swim down to a lost city.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
One of the best ways to explore mainland Greece is under your own steam, through the myriad activities on offer here. There are opportunities to don a mask and flippers and snorkel over an ancient submerged city; to climb Mount Olympus, the fabled home of Zeus, king of the gods; to leap into a boat and whitewater-raft down a 7.5-mile-long gorge; and to ski through the quiet backcountry of its Peloponnese mountain range.
Created during a 1960s hydroelectric project to dam four rivers, Greeceâ€™s biggest artificial lake is a fjord-likâ€¦

entry.title: Going to Japan? Here's how to collect station stamps
entry.summary: Japanese station stamps, or eki stamps, can be collecting in most train stations and many tourist attractions in Japan. Japanese eki stamps (station stamps) are a charming feature of Japanese railway culture. Beloved by visitors and oshi-tetsu (train-stamp nerds) alike, collecting them as you make your way around Japan is easy and free, and results in a unique and lasting record of your journey. Hereâ€™s everything you need to know about creating your own eki stamp collection. This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). Now ubiquitous in many of Japanâ€™s 9,000 stations, the first eki stamp appeared in 1931 at Fukui station near the Sea of Japan coast, where stationmaster Kanichi Tominaga hit upon the idea of a commemorative stamp after a casual conveâ€¦

entry.title: We tried out Pedro Pascalâ€™s â€˜The Last of Usâ€™ jacket. Hereâ€™s our full review.
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
On April 13, the second season of HBOâ€™s The Last of Us picks up the harrowing journey that Joel and Ellie (played by Pedro Pascal and Bella Ramsey) take across a world decimated by a runaway fungal virus. Also returning? Joelâ€™s Huckberry Flint and Tinder Flannel Lined Waxed Trucker Jacket thatâ€”like the showâ€”has become a real-world hit, selling out everywhere.Â
Thatâ€™s understandableâ€”after all, any jacket that can stand up to cordyceps-riddled zombieâ€¦

entry.title: This was a hotspot for great white sharksâ€”then they vanished
entry.summary:
Built like a torpedo with rows of terrifying 2.5-inch teeth, the worldâ€™s largest predatory shark is an intimidating sight. So intimidating that some might think an ocean without great white sharks (Carcharodon carcharias) would be a good thing. But their loss causes a ripple effect that transforms the entire ecosystem.
A new study in Frontiers in Marine Science shows what happens when sharks vanish. Seal Island, off South Africa's False Bay was once a great white hotspotâ€”one of the few places on Earth where the sharks could be seen surging out of the water to capture prey.
â€œIt was air Jaws,â€ says marine ecologist Neil Hammerschlag, executive director of the Shark Research Foundation Inc. and a coauthor on the new study. â€œI don't think there's anything more remarkable in nature thâ€¦

entry.title: 5 places with the most incredible running trails in the world
entry.summary: Runners competing in the Marakez Pyramids Half Marathon in Cairo, Egypt. Imagine running with a view of the Pyramids of Giza or inside the valley of a dormant volcano. The new book 100 Runs of a Lifetime has a must-visit destination for anyone who loves a good runâ€”no matter your skill level. From the Pyramids of Giza in Egypt to the PouÄkai Circuit in New Zealand to HaleakalÄ National Park in Maui, there are many incredible running trails all over the world. The new National Geographic book, 100 Runs of a Lifetime, written by Bart Yasso (who served as the chief running officer for 30 years at Runner's World magazine), explores all of these destinations and more. Here are five running trails that are worth traveling for. Egypt Cairo is a popular destination for trâ€¦

entry.title: Countries reach historic deal to cut shipping emissions
entry.summary: After years of intense negotiations, countries on Friday reached a landmark deal to cut greenhouse gas emissions from global shipping, setting mandatory fuel standards and introducing an industry-wide carbon pricing mechanism.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar: Military strikes persist amid earthquake response efforts
entry.summary: Military operations continue in Myanmar despite ceasefires declared after the recent earthquake that killed more than 3,600 people, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo crisis: Children subjected to deliberate, systemic sexual violence
entry.summary: Sexual violence against children in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) has reached staggering proportions, with the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) reporting thousands of new cases in just two months â€“ evidence that itâ€™s being used as a systemic weapon of war and deliberate terror tactic.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: US tariffs move could see three per cent fall in global trade, says top UN economist
entry.summary: Global trade could shrink by three per cent as a result of the United Statesâ€™ new tariff measures which in the longer term could reshape and boost as-yet untapped regional commercial links, a top UN economist confirmed on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN refugee agency calls for greater investment in Syrian returnees
entry.summary: Roughly 400,000 Syrians have returned home from the region since the fall of the Assad regime last December, while more than a million internally displaced persons (IDPs) have gone back to their communities.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: UN rights office condemns Israeli buffer zone plan
entry.summary: The UN human rights office said on Friday it fears that Israel may intend to permanently remove civilians in Gaza as part of an expanded buffer zone, amid evacuations orders and escalating bombardment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war has created suffering of â€˜industrial proportionsâ€™, aid agencies warn
entry.summary: Two years since Sudanâ€™s brutal conflict began, UN agencies warned that famine is spreading and civilians of all ages continue to suffer shocking abuse, including rape and gang rape.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Do crossword puzzles really keep your brain sharp?
entry.summary:
An elderly person works on a crossword puzzle. These games can help keep the brain engagedâ€”but studies show other habits, like exercise and education, play a far greater role in preventing cognitive decline. Theyâ€™ve long been seen as a way to prevent cognitive declineâ€”but experts say the real key to brain health goes far beyond word games.
Ask almost anyone how to stay mentally sharp in old age; chances are someone will bring up crossword puzzles. Alongside Sudoku and word searches, these games have long been seen as â€œworkoutsâ€ for the brain. In fact, a 2020 study published in Frontiers in Human Neuroscience found these kinds of puzzles are among the most frequently engaged-in activities for brain training and cognitive benefits.
But how did this belief become so widespread? Aâ€¦

entry.title: Follow the divine topography of this Greek pilgrimage for monks
entry.summary:
The Rousanou Monastery was founded in the 14th century and is one of six still in use in the Meteora region. The region of Meteora combines outlandish topography and improbable architecture to divine effect.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As the sun sinks towards the serrated horizon of the distant Pindus Mountains, the assembled congregation grows quiet. There are perhaps 40 people gathered here, each occupying their own smooth knuckle of the lofty outcrop. Some have been present an hour or more, watching the day slowly drain from this extraordinary landscape. Others, such as myself, a matter of minutes â€” fortuitously passing Meteoraâ€™s most celebrated sunset spot as dusk closes in.
Itâ€™s quite the vantage point: all around, thrusting uâ€¦

entry.title: Who is General Tsoâ€”and why does he have his own chicken dish?
entry.summary:
This iconic chicken dish was created for an American generalâ€”but named after a Chinese one. While the entrÃ©e was originally created in Taiwan, the recipe was actually specifically crafted for American eaters from the very start.
For the past fifty years, few dishes have defined Chinese-American cuisine quite like General Tsoâ€™s chicken. With its glistening, deep-fried crunch and sticky, sweet-savory glaze, itâ€™s become a staple on takeout menus across the United States.
But the dish was never meant to reflect traditional Chinese cooking. Although it originated in Taiwan, General Tsoâ€™s chicken was purposefully crafted to seduce the American palate from the very beginning.
(Peking duck: the complex history of a Chinese classic.)
The original version of General Tsoâ€™s câ€¦

entry.title: Was Cyrus the Great really a tolerant conqueror?
entry.summary: The Achaemenid kings of Persia ruled between the sixth and fourth centuries B.C., but much of what we know about them today comes from Greek rather than Persian sources. The various Greek authors who wrote about the Persians tended to depict them as decadent and weak-willed, ruled by a series of self-styled great kings. Persian culture was often contrasted with the austerity of Athens and Sparta. The stories of Persian kings that have filtered down through Greek works of philosophy, history, and plays mix firsthand observations with a large dose of fiction and fantasy. It should be remembered that the Greeks saw the might of Persia as a huge threat. For half a century they were engaged in the Greco-Persian wars (499-449 B.C.), fighting to keep that threat at bay, and this enmity shaped howâ€¦

entry.title: An insiderâ€™s guide to Nantes
entry.summary:
Set on Franceâ€™s Loire river, roughly 30 miles before it meets the Atlantic Ocean, the colourful city of Nantes is a cultural and artistic hub with a whimsical spirit. With contemporary art installations around every corner and several innovative museums, the city's creative side is prominent, while its Breton identity also remains strong â€” in the 15th century, Nantes was the seat of the dukes of Brittany, before the independent kingdom became part of France in 1532.
Even the cityâ€™s industrial past is treated with an artistic reverence â€” on the site of its former shipyards on the Ãle de Nantes (an island on the Loire river), you'll find Les Machines de lâ€™Ã®le, a collection of mechanical creations, including a 40ft-tall elephant that carries passengers around the concourse and sprays watâ€¦

entry.title: Why do birds sing so loudly in spring? Itâ€™s the â€˜dawn chorusâ€™
entry.summary:
As spring begins, so does a fresh song at daybreak, unique to the season. Just before the sun rises, birds start singing their melodies, creating a chirpy symphony.Â
This phenomenon is known as the dawn chorus, and itâ€™s special for a number of reasons: There are more birds singing at this time of year, and they also sing more often. This energetic burst of birdsong is often louder than usual too. The dawn chorusâ€™ early morning explosion of sounds has even inspired multipleÂ poemsÂ andÂ songs.Â
â€œIt's the epitome of spring,â€ says Jordan E. Rutter, an ornithologist at the American Bird Conservancy. After the long and cold winter, â€œall of a sudden you have this influx of so many beautiful birds coming back and singing.â€
This harmony of birdsong at dawn happens during a fundamental â€¦

entry.title: Dust isnâ€™t just dirtâ€”itâ€™s full of â€˜forever chemicalsâ€™
entry.summary:
Dust may seem like a harmless nuisanceâ€”but experts say those tiny particles that are floating in the air or accumulating in clumps under your couch or on your windowsill may actually cause more harm than you think.
â€œMost people think dust is gross but I donâ€™t think people associate dust with the potential health harms it may contain,â€ says Tasha Stoiber, a senior scientist at the Environmental Working Group. â€œIt might not be peopleâ€™s number one cleaning priority.â€
But it should be high on the list of priorities because dust isnâ€™t just dirt. It contains a blend of various substances, including dead skin cells, hair fragments, pet dander, clothing and furniture fibers, dust mites, mold and fungi spores, microplastic particles, as well as allergens (such as pollen), bacteria, and soâ€¦

entry.title: Americans knew their booze was poisonedâ€”and drank it anyway
entry.summary:
When bluesman Ishman Bracey poured himself a drink in Jackson, Mississippi, he didnâ€™t know his luck had just run as dry as the nationâ€™s taps.
A couple of weeks later, his legs were tingling. With rumors of a polio surge going around, he rushed to the hospital. But it wasnâ€™t a virus. Heâ€™d been poisoned.
The cause? A government policy that made drinking alcohol not just illegalâ€”but lethal.Â
During Prohibition, not all alcohol was banned â€”Â just drinkable, non-medicinal alcohol. To prevent bootleggers from repurposing industrial alcohol, the U.S. government launched what it called the â€œNoble Experiment,â€ adding toxic chemicals like methanol and benzene to render it undrinkable. According to a New York Times headline at the time, the government planned to â€œdouble alcohol poison câ€¦

entry.title: These are the best waterproof pants, according to adventurers
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*
Outdoor adventures are full of thrilling, unexpected moments, from wildlife sightings and jaw-dropping viewsâ€”to surprise downpours. Being prepared for any weather is key.Â Â
â€œWaterproof pants are important because staying dry means staying warm,â€ says Jonathan Grenier, founder of Ungava Polar Eco-Tours, an ecotourism company based in sub-Arctic Quebec. When guiding groups, Grenier often spends long hours trekking or boating in unpredictable conditionâ€¦

entry.title: How this sleepy Southern town became an art lover's paradise
entry.summary:
Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art was designed by renowned architect Moshe Safdie. With a world-class art museum, 70 miles of hiking and biking trails, and a thriving culinary scene, Bentonville, Arkansas, has emerged as a must-visit family-friendly getaway.
Bentonville, Arkansas, has emerged as a lively artistic and culinary destination, driven by the influence of the renowned Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art. Thanks to this cultural influx, and with plenty to capture the attention of parents and children alike, it's also a perfect getaway for families.
This area has long been known as a masterpiece of wild, wooded beauty. Situated on a plateau among the Ozark Mountains, Bentonvilleâ€™s network of nearly 70 miles of trails within the city connect to 400 miles of mounâ€¦

entry.title: How a penguin 'massacre' led to new protections in Argentina
entry.summary:
As spring turns to summer in the southern hemisphere, the Punta Tombo Natural Protected Area on Argentinaâ€™s central coast comes alive, with the chicks of some 180,000 pairs of nesting Magellanic penguins braying and peeping 24/7.
That penguin-palooza was nearing a crescendo in November 2021 when tragedy struck. A local rancher named Ricardo La Regina, then 33, intentionally drove a backhoe through nesting grounds just north of Punta Tombo, home to the worldâ€™s second-largest Magellanic penguin colony and part of the UNESCOâ€™s Patagonia Azul Biosphere Reserve. An estimated 175 nests were crushed and more than 100 penguins killed in what the Argentine press dubbed the â€œPunta Tombo Penguin Massacre.â€
But after a historic court case, some surprising good has come from the disaster, incâ€¦

(D1 è¯»å–å¤åˆ¶é€šè¿‡å°†è¯»å–æŸ¥è¯¢åˆ†æµåˆ°è¯»å–å‰¯æœ¬ï¼Œæé«˜äº†æ•´ä½“ååé‡ï¼Œä»è€Œä½¿ä¸»æ•°æ®åº“èƒ½å¤Ÿå¤„ç†æ›´å¤šçš„å†™å…¥æŸ¥è¯¢ã€‚) The sessions implementation ensures sequential consistency for all queries in the sessionï¼Œ no matter what copy of the database each query is routed to. entry.title: How winemakers of color are changing South Africa's wine scene
entry.summary:
South African winemakers are ringing in a new dawn for local viniculture. South Africaâ€™s winemakers of colour are changing the countryâ€™s viticulture, creating a crop of bold new brands.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Pick up almost any bottle of South African wine, and itâ€™s unlikely to have been made by a winemaker of colour. But things are changing. Thereâ€™s an increasing determination to improve opportunities, notably for young South Africans who want to enter the industry. Initiatives such as the Cape Winemakers Guild (CWG) ProtegÃ© programme, which enables newly graduated winemakers from disadvantaged backgrounds to spend time working with some of the countryâ€™s leading winemakers, have benefited several award-winning youngsters. They inclâ€¦

entry.title: Myanmar: UN seeks additional $240 million to bolster earthquake relief
entry.summary: The United Nations is ramping up its response to Myanmarâ€™s devastating earthquake, calling for increased funding and an immediate ceasefire to ensure more aid reaches those in desperate need.

entry.title: Bombardment, deprivation and displacement continue in Gaza
entry.summary: Hostilities across the Gaza Strip continue to take a devastating toll on the population, with daily reports of Israeli strikes killing and injuring many civilians, UN aid coordination office OCHA said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan faces unprecedented hunger and displacement as war enters third year
entry.summary: The conflict in Sudan has become one of the worst humanitarian crises of the 21st century, leaving millions of women, children and displaced families suffering from violence, food insecurity and the collapse of essential services.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WHO warns of severe disruptions to health services amid funding cuts
entry.summary: Recent funding cuts have caused â€œsevere disruptionsâ€ to health services in almost three-quarters of all countries, according to the head of the UN World Health Organization (WHO),Â Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Spare developing countries from new US tariffs: UN trade chief
entry.summary: As governments and global markets struggle to deal with the deep concerns and disruptions caused by trade tariffs, Rebeca Grynspan, the head of the UN trade and development agency (UNCTAD), told UN News on Thursday that the poorest countries â€“ whose activities have a negligible effect on trade deficits â€“ should be exempt.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syriaâ€™s political transition at risk due to Israeli military action, Security Council hears
entry.summary: Recent military actions by Israel are undermining Syriaâ€™s political transition and the chances of a new security pact between the two countries, a senior UN official told the Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World Court begins hearing Sudanâ€™s â€˜complicity in genocideâ€™ case against the United Arab Emirates
entry.summary: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) on Thursday began hearing Sudanâ€™s case against the United Arab Emirates (UAE), which it accuses of being complicit in acts of genocide against the Masalit community in West Darfur by backing the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Preventable â€˜meningitis beltâ€™ deaths targeted in health agency action plan
entry.summary: Millions of deaths could be avoided from meningitis if countries are able to adopt new guidelines designed to diagnose and treat the disease more effectively, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Thursday.

entry.title: Isabel Ravenna
entry.summary: New

entry.title: Why Scotlandâ€™s Argyll & the Isles should be your next getaway
entry.summary:
West of Glasgow, the peninsula of Argyll stretches towards its cluster of neighbouring isles, which fan out in all their marvellous diversity. Although small on the map, this part of Scotland has more than 2,300 miles of coast â€” about as much as South Africa â€” and 23 inhabited islands, each with their own character. After exploring the mainlandâ€™s castles and lochs, head to the fishing port of Oban to fill up on lobsters and mussels. From there, you can depart for an island adventure where you might set forth in a sea kayak, get a taste of the regionâ€™s 24 whisky and gin distilleries, or scale a mighty Munro â€” a mountain that towers above 3,000 ft. From sipping scotch fireside, to navigating wild Atlantic coastlines, hereâ€™s how to explore Scotland's rugged western shores.
Argyll & theâ€¦

entry.title: Love reading? These are the best book towns around the world
entry.summary:
Wigtown, known as "Scotland's Book Town," has a 10-day literary festival every fall. In these small towns from Scotland to New Zealand, books shape identity, tourism, and community. 
In the Welsh village of Hay-on-Wye, where sheep outnumber people and books spill onto the streets, a quiet revolution began. Antiquarian and academic Richard Booth inadvertently launched a global movement when he began filling the empty buildings of Hay-on-Wye with secondhand books.
What started as a single decision in 1961 to fill his sleepy hometown with secondhand books to sell in numerous empty buildings, turned into the birthplace of a global literary mecca uniting villages, bibliophiles, and dreamers alike.Â
People from across the United Kingdom swarmed this small town, and soon boâ€¦

entry.title: Why is everyone looking up in Tucson?
entry.summary:
Nine people are crammed in a tiny room with no ceiling on the grounds ofÂ Kitt Peak National Observatory. Itâ€™s cold. Itâ€™s dark. Each person awaits a turn at the eyepiece of a 20-inch telescope trained on an object. A marbled sphere, swirled in colors of maroon, rust, and cream. Itâ€™s Jupiter, a fellow planet in our solar system, fifth from the sun. â€œLook at that black speck that kinda looks like dirt on the lens,â€ says guide James Schweder. â€œThatâ€™s Io, one of Jupiterâ€™s moons, casting its shadow on the planet.â€ He puts the show in perspective. â€œYouâ€™re basically watching a solar eclipse from more than 417 million miles away.â€Â
With a surfeit of blockbuster attractions as the Grand Canyon, Sedona, Monument Valley and the Hoover Dam in the state, travelers to Arizona can be forgiven for oâ€¦
